description: From Middle English warmth, warmeth, wermþe, from Old English *wiermþu (“warmth”), from Proto-West Germanic *warmiþu (“warmness; warmth”), corresponding to warm +‎ -th. Cognate with Saterland Frisian Waarmte (“warmth”), West Frisian waarmte (“warmth”), Dutch warmte (“warmth”), German Low German Warmte, Warmt (“warmth”).

entries.meaning: A moderate degree of heat; the sensation of being warm.
Fervor, intensity of emotion or expression.
(art) The effect of using mostly red and yellow hues.
